newsitem.title: USA: Albright says no plan to extend Bosnia troop stay.
newsitem.headline: Albright says no plan to extend Bosnia troop stay.

text.p: Secretary of State Madeleine Albright said on Friday there were no plans for U.S. troops to remain in Bosnia after June 1998, and denied she had any disagreement with the Pentagon on the issue.

But Albright said civilian implementation of the Dayton peace accords for Bosnia had been "lagging" and needed to be stepped up in conjunction with the military stabilisation force (SFOR) currently in the Balkan republic.

A U.S. official, speaking anonymously on Thursday, left open the possibility that U.S. troops, which form the bulk of the SFOR, could stay in Bosnia beyond a June 1998 deadline, although Defence Secretary Willam Cohen has said the deadline was firm.
"There is not a disagreement between me and the Pentagon," Albright told a news conference. "We have no plans for any lengthening of the role of American forces."
But, she added, "We as the administration believe that the civilian implementation has been lagging."
"We have determined that we need to invigorate the civilian implementation and the cooperation between the civilian and the military within the mandate that the military has," Albright said.
